g4601.definition: [σιγάω] from {{g4602}}; to keep silent (transitively or intransitively)

g4602.definition: [σιγή] apparently from σίζω (to hiss, i.e. hist or hush); silence Compare {{g4623}}.

g4605.definition: [Σιδών] of Hebrew origin ({{h6721}}); Sidon (i.e. Tsidon), a place in Palestine

g4606.definition: [Σιδώνιος] from {{g4605}}; a Sidonian, i.e. inhabitant of Sidon

g4607.definition: [σικάριος] of Latin origin; a dagger-man or assassin; a freebooter (Jewish fanatic outlawed by the Romans) Compare {{g5406}}.

g4608.definition: [σίκερα] of Hebrew origin ({{h7941}}); an intoxicant, i.e. intensely fermented liquor

g4610.definition: [Σιλουανός] of Latin origin; "silvan"; Silvanus, a Christian Compare {{g4609}}.

g4611.definition: [Σιλωάμ] of Hebrew origin ({{h7975}}); Siloam (i.e. Shiloach), a pool of Jerusalem

g4612.definition: [σιμικίνθιον] of Latin origin; a semicinctium or half-girding, i.e. narrow covering (apron)

g4613.definition: [Σίμων] of Hebrew origin ({{h8095}}); Simon (i.e. Shimon), the name of nine Israelites Compare {{g4826}}.

g4614.definition: [Σινᾶ] of Hebrew origin ({{h5514}}); Sina (i.e. Sinai), a mountain in Arabia

g4615.definition: [σίναπι] perhaps from σίνομαι (to hurt, i.e. sting); mustard (the plant)

g4616.definition: [σινδών] of uncertain (perhaps foreign) origin; byssos, i.e. bleached linen (the cloth or a garment of it)

g4618.definition: [σιτευτός] from a derivative of {{g4621}}; grain-fed, i.e. fattened

g4619.definition: [σιτιστός] from a derivative of {{g4621}}; grained, i.e. fatted

g4620.definition: [σιτόμετρον] from {{g4621}} and {{g3358}}; a grain-measure, i.e. (by implication) ration (allowance of food)

g4621.definition: [σῖτος] , also plural irregular neuter      σῖταof uncertain derivation; grain, especially wheat

g4622.definition: [Σιών] of Hebrew origin ({{h6726}}); Sion (i.e. Tsijon), a hill of Jerusalem; figuratively, the Church (militant or triumphant)

g4623.definition: [σιωπάω] from σιωπή (silence, i.e. a hush; properly, muteness, i.e. involuntary stillness, or inability to speak; and thus differing from {{g4602}}, which is rather a voluntary refusal or indisposition to speak, although the terms are often used synonymously); to be dumb (but not deaf also, like 2974 properly); figuratively, to be calm (as quiet water)

g4624.definition: [σκανδαλίζω] from {{g4625}}; to entrap, i.e. trip up (figuratively, stumble (transitively) or entice to sin, apostasy or displeasure)

g4625.definition: [σκάνδαλον] ("scandal"); probably from a derivative of {{g2578}}; a  trap-stick (bent sapling), i.e. snare (figuratively, cause of displeasure or sin)

g4626.definition: [σκάπτω] apparently a primary verb; to dig

g4627.definition: [σκάφη] a "skiff" (as if dug out), or yawl (carried aboard a large vessel for landing)

g4628.definition: [σκέλος] apparently from σκέλλω (to parch; through the idea of leanness); the leg (as lank)

g4629.definition: [σκέπασμα] from a derivative of σκέπας (a covering; perhaps akin to the base of {{g4649}} through the idea of noticeableness); clothing

g4630.definition: [Σκευᾶς] apparently of Latin origin; left-handed; Scevas (i.e. Scævus), an Israelite

g4632.definition: [σκεῦος] of uncertain affinity; a vessel, implement, equipment or apparatus (literally or figuratively [specially, a wife as contributing to the usefulness of the husband])

g4633.definition: [σκηνή] apparently akin to {{g4632}} and {{g4639}}; a tent or cloth hut (literally or figuratively)

g4634.definition: [σκηνοπηγία] from {{g4636}} and {{g4078}}; the Festival of Tabernacles (so called from the custom of erecting booths for temporary homes)

g4635.definition: [σκηνοποιός] from {{g4633}} and {{g4160}}; a manufacturer of tents

g4636.definition: [σκῆνος] from {{g4633}}; a hut or temporary residence, i.e. (figuratively) the human body (as the abode of the spirit)

g4637.definition: [σκηνόω] from {{g4636}}; to tent or encamp, i.e. (figuratively) to occupy (as a mansion) or (specially), to reside (as God did in the Tabernacle of old, a symbol of protection and communion)

g4638.definition: [σκήνωμα] from {{g4637}}; an encampment, i.e. (figuratively) the Temple (as God's residence), the body (as a tenement for the soul)

g4639.definition: [σκιά] apparently a primary word; "shade" or a shadow (literally or figuratively (darkness of error or an adumbration))

g4640.definition: [σκιρτάω] akin to σκαίρω (to skip); to jump, i.e. sympathetically move (as the quickening of a fetus)

g4641.definition: [σκληροκαρδία] feminine of a compound of {{g4642}} and {{g2588}}; hard-heartedness, i.e. (specially), destitution of (spiritual) perception

g4642.definition: [σκληρός] from the base of {{g4628}}; dry, i.e. hard or tough (figuratively, harsh, severe)

g4645.definition: [σκληρύνω] from {{g4642}}; to indurate, i.e. (figuratively) render stubborn

g4646.definition: [σκολιός] from the base of {{g4628}}; warped, i.e. winding; figuratively, perverse

g4647.definition: [σκόλοψ] perhaps from the base of {{g4628}} and {{g3700}}; withered at the front, i.e. a point or prickle (figuratively, a bodily annoyance or disability)

g4648.definition: [σκοπέω] from {{g4649}}; to take aim at (spy), i.e. (figuratively) regard Compare {{g3700}}.

g4649.definition: [σκοπός] from σκέπτομαι (to peer about ("skeptic"); perhaps akin to {{g4626}} through the idea of concealment; compare {{g4629}}); a watch (sentry or scout), i.e. (by implication) a goal

g4650.definition: [σκορπίζω] apparently from the same as {{g4651}} (through the idea of penetrating); to dissipate, i.e. (figuratively) put to flight, waste, be liberal

g4651.definition: [σκορπίος] probably from an obsolete σκέρπω (perhaps strengthened from the base of {{g4649}} and meaning to pierce); a "scorpion" (from its sting)

g4655.definition: [σκότος] from the base of {{g4639}}; shadiness, i.e. obscurity (literally or figuratively)

g4656.definition: [σκοτόω] from {{g4655}}; to obscure or blind (literally or figuratively)

g4657.definition: [σκύβαλον] neuter of a presumed derivative of {{g1519}} and {{g2965}} and {{g906}}; what is thrown to the dogs, i.e. refuse (ordure)

g4658.definition: [Σκύθης] probably of foreign origin; a Scythene or Scythian, i.e. (by implication) a savage

g4659.definition: [σκυθρωπός] from σκυθρός (sullen) and a derivative of {{g3700}}; angry-visaged, i.e. gloomy or affecting a mournful appearance

g4660.definition: [σκύλλω] apparently a primary verb; to flay, i.e. (figuratively) to harass

g4661.definition: [σκῦλον] neuter from {{g4660}}; something stripped (as a hide), i.e. booty

g4662.definition: [σκωληκόβρωτος] from {{g4663}} and a derivative of {{g977}}; worm-eaten, i.e. diseased with maggots

g4663.definition: [σκώληξ] of uncertain derivation; a grub, maggot or earth-worm

g4665.definition: [σμάραγδος] of uncertain derivation; the emerald or green gem so called

g4667.definition: [Σμύρνα] the same as {{g4666}}; Smyrna, a place in Asia Minor

g4669.definition: [σμυρνίζω] from {{g4667}}; to tincture with myrrh, i.e. embitter (as a narcotic)

g4670.definition: [Σόδομα] plural of Hebrew origin ({{h5467}}); Sodoma (i.e. Sedom), a place in Palestine

g4672.definition: [Σολομών] of Hebrew origin ({{h8010}}); Solomon (i.e. Shelomoh), the son of David

g4673.definition: [σορός] probably akin to the base of {{g4987}}; a funereal receptacle (urn, coffin), i.e. (by analogy) a bier

g4675.definition: [σοῦ] genitive case of {{g4771}}; of thee, thy

g4676.definition: [σουδάριον] of Latin origin; a sudarium (sweat-cloth), i.e. towel (for wiping the perspiration from the face, or binding the face of a corpse)

g4677.definition: [Σουσάννα] of Hebrew origin ({{h7799}} feminine); lily; Susannah (i.e. Shoshannah), an Israelitess

g4678.definition: [σοφία] from {{g4680}}; wisdom (higher or lower, worldly or spiritual)

g4679.definition: [σοφίζω] from {{g4680}}; to render wise; in a sinister acceptation, to form "sophisms", i.e. continue plausible error

g4680.definition: [σοφός] akin to σαφής (clear); wise (in a most general application) Compare {{g5429}}.

g4681.definition: [Σπανία] probably of foreign origin; Spania, a region of Europe

g4682.definition: [σπαράσσω] prolongation from σπαίρω (to grasp; apparently strengthened from {{g4685}} through the idea of spasmodic contraction); to mangle, i.e. convluse with epilepsy

g4683.definition: [σπαργανόω] from σπάργανον (a strip; from a derivative of the base of {{g4682}} meaning to strap or wrap with strips); to swathe (an infant after the Oriental custom)

g4686.definition: [σπεῖρα] of immediate Latin origin, but ultimately a derivative of {{g138}} in the sense of its cognate {{g1507}}; a coil (spira, "spire"), i.e. (figuratively) a mass of men (a Roman military cohort; also (by analogy) a squad of Levitical janitors)

g4687.definition: [σπείρω] probably strengthened from {{g4685}} (through the idea of extending); to scatter, i.e. sow (literally or figuratively)

g4688.definition: [σπεκουλάτωρ] of Latin origin; a speculator, i.e. military scout (spy or (by extension) life-guardsman)

g4689.definition: [σπένδω] apparently a primary verb; to pour out as a libation, i.e. (figuratively) to devote (one's life or blood, as a sacrifice) ("spend")

g4690.definition: [σπέρμα] from {{g4687}}; something sown, i.e. seed (including the male "sperm"); by implication, offspring; specially, a remnant (figuratively, as if kept over for planting)

g4691.definition: [σπερμολόγος] from {{g4690}} and {{g3004}}; a seed-picker (as the crow), i.e. (figuratively) a sponger, loafer (specially, a gossip or trifler in talk)

g4692.definition: [σπεύδω] probably strengthened from {{g4228}}; to "speed" ("study"), i.e. urge on (diligently or earnestly); by implication, to await eagerly

g4693.definition: [σπήλαιον] neuter of a presumed derivative of σπέος (a grotto); a cavern; by implication, a hiding-place or resort

g4694.definition: [σπιλάς] of uncertain derivation; a ledge or reef of rock in the sea

g4695.definition: [σπιλόω] from {{g4696}}; to stain or soil (literally or figuratively)

g4696.definition: [σπίλος] of uncertain derivation; a stain or blemish, i.e. (figuratively) defect, disgrace

g4697.definition: [σπλαγχνίζομαι] middle voice from {{g4698}}; to have the bowels yearn, i.e. (figuratively) feel sympathy, to pity

g4698.definition: [σπλάγχνον] probably strengthened from σπλήν (the "spleen"); an intestine (plural); figuratively, pity or sympathy
